head.title: In Malawi, Free Press And Enough Food

hedline.hl1: In Malawi, Free Press And Enough Food

block.p: In "Vast Africa Defies Easy Generalizations" (letter, Nov. 21), P. P. Lakshman alleges that Malawi has no free press or radio. There is lively press coverage in Malawi, and contributors to papers circulating in the country are free to write whatever they want, provided they observe the legal limits and appreciate the sensitivities of the people of the country. This is true too of radio under the Malawi Broadcasting Corporation.

In "Vast Africa Defies Easy Generalizations" (letter, Nov. 21), P. P. Lakshman alleges that Malawi has no free press or radio. There is lively press coverage in Malawi, and contributors to papers circulating in the country are free to write whatever they want, provided they observe the legal limits and appreciate the sensitivities of the people of the country. This is true too of radio under the Malawi Broadcasting Corporation.

Mr. Lakshman categorizes the leadership of President H. Kamuzu Banda as authoritarian. Dr. Banda is a leader who knows what is good for his people and can not only give instructions, but also see that they are carried out. He is, in other words, an effective chief executive.

The only point on which I can agree with Mr. Lakshman is that Dr. Banda insists, and makes sure, that his people have enough to eat throughout the year. I do not understand why a leader who insures his people have enough to eat cannot be praised and given support. ROBERT B. MBAYA Ambassador from Malawi Washington, Nov. 21, 1991
